raw_text:
Asia shares defy post-quake gloom
 
 Indonesian, Indian and Hong Kong stock markets reached record highs.
 
 Investors seemed to feel that some of the worst-affected areas were so under-developed that the tragedy would have little impact on Asia's listed firms. "Obviously with a lot of loss of life, a lot of time is needed to clean up the mess, bury the people and find the missing," said ABN Amro's Eddie Wong. "[But] it's not necessarily a really big thing in the economic sense."
 
 India's Bombay Stock Exchange inched slightly above its previous record close on Wednesday. Expectations of strong corporate earnings in 2005 drove the Indonesian stock exchange in Jakarta to a record high on Wednesday. In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index may be benefiting in part from the potential for its listed property companies to gain from rebuilding contracts in the tsunami-affected regions of South East Asia. In Sri Lanka, some economists have said that as much as 1% of annual growth may be lost. Sri Lanka's stock market has fallen about 5% since the weekend, but it is still 40% higher than at the start of 2004.
 
 Thailand may lose 30bn baht (£398m; $768m) in earnings from tourism over the next three months, according to tourism minister Sontaya Kunplome.
 
 In the affected provinces, he expects the loss of tourism revenue to be offset by government reconstruction spending. Thailand intends to spend a similar sum - around 30bn baht - on the rebuilding work. "It will take until the fourth quarter of next year before tourist visitors in Phuket and five other provinces return to their normal level," said Naris Chaiyasoot, director general at the ministry's fiscal policy office. In the Maldives the cost of reconstruction could wipe out economic growth, according to a government spokesman. "Our nation is in peril here," said Ahmed Shaheed, the chief government spokesman. He estimated the economic cost of the disaster at hundreds of millions of dollars. The Maldives has gross domestic product of $660m. "It won't be surprising if the cost exceeds our GDP," he said. "In the last few years, we made great progress in our standard of living - the United Nations recognised this. Now we see this can disappear in a few days, a few minutes." Shaheed noted that investment in a single tourist resort - the economic mainstay - could run to $40m. Between 10 and 12 of the 80-odd resorts have been severely damaged, and a similar number have suffered significant damage.
 
 However, many experts, including the World Bank, have pointed out that it is still difficult to assess the magnitude of the disaster and its likely economic impact. In part, this is because of its scale, and because delivering aid and recovering the dead remain priorities. "Calculators will have to wait," said an IMF official in a briefing on Wednesday. "The financial and world community will be turning toward reconstruction efforts and at that point people will begin to have a sense of the financial impact."

llama3.2:3b: Asian stock markets reached record highs despite the devastating post-quake gloom, with investors downplaying the economic impact due to the region's underdeveloped areas.
Thailand may lose £398m in tourism earnings over three months, but expects government reconstruction spending to offset losses.
The Maldives' economy could be wiped out by reconstruction costs, estimated at hundreds of millions of dollars.
gemma2:2b: Asian stock markets are reaching record highs despite the devastating tsunami.
While some economists predict a slight dip in certain Asian nations, particularly Sri Lanka and Thailand due to tourism losses, others believe rebuilding efforts will offset these declines.
The Maldives is facing a potential economic collapse due to significant damage to its tourism-based economy.
However, experts emphasize that the true economic impact of the disaster will be clearer once reconstruction efforts begin.

Some economists expect Asia's listed firms to suffer less than other parts of the world from the earthquake-induced tsunami.
The affected regions may face additional challenges in rebuilding their economies due to infrastructure damage.
Investors are concerned about potential economic losses related to tourism and reconstruction efforts.

Economic effects will depend on the severity of the tsunami and overall recovery efforts.

In Sri Lanka, growth is expected to decrease by 1%, while Thailand's tourism sector may suffer significantly due to $398m loss in revenue and ongoing reconstruction efforts.

Indonesia and Hong Kong saw their exchanges hit new peaks amid expectations of strong corporate earnings in 2005.
India’s BSE remained above its previous high on Wednesday.
The Hang Seng index benefited from potential rebuilding contracts in the tsunami-affected regions.

While some countries like Sri Lanka may lose 1% of annual growth, others are facing significant challenges such as Thailand losing up to £398m in tourism earnings and Maldives expecting economic costs exceeding $660m GDP.
Experts note that assessing the disaster's impact remains challenging due to ongoing aid efforts and recovery work.

The Asia Share Defies Post-Quake Gloom

Indonesian, Indian and Hong Kong stock markets reached record highs by the end of the day.
Investors seemed to feel that some areas were under-developed, causing a tragic outcome.
"It's not necessarily a big thing in the economic sense," said ABN Amro's Eddie Wong.
However, it is certainly an important factor for Asian firms.
The loss of life and time are necessary for the recovery of the damaged structures and people.
India's Bombay Stock Exchange showed a slight increase in close range on Wednesday, expecting strong earnings in 2005.
In the world of economies, it’s estimated that a good deal of investment can be recovered after a tsunami-affected region like South East Asia.
In Sri Lanka, the economy's expected growth rate may be cut by about 1%.
However, it is still 40% higher than at the start of 2004.
In the affected provinces, he expects to offset the lost tourism revenue from the disaster in the upcoming months.
Maldives, a major player in the region, has been at a loss for significant economic gain over the years - probably due to a recovery from a catastrophic event.
The cost of reconstruction could wipe out economic growth, but it might be worth it if the economy's recovery can lead to improved economic performance.
Thailand, as a global investor, expects the economic boom in the next three months to offset the tourism costs and expenses spent on construction projects.
However, many experts say that it is still challenging to assess the magnitude of the disaster and its likely economic impact.
The cost of a single tourist resort, which could be $40m, makes travelling economically feasible.
However, it will need to wait until the next few years before people in Phuket and other provinces can start returning, a forecast made by the World Bank.

The Indian and Hong Kong stock exchanges may benefit from rebuilding contracts in the affected regions.

tinyllama:1.1b: In Asia, despite a drop in stock prices after the devastating Indian Ocean tsunami, investors seem undeterred by the catastrophic disaster and are optimistic about the region's listed firms.
While some areas may experience short-term impact, the potential for corporate earnings rebundling and government reconstruction spendings could offset losses over a longer period.
The post-quake gloom has been broken up by strong corporate earnings and economic growth in the affected provinces of Thailand, Indonesia, and Malaysia.

However, investors are still unsure about the magnitude of the disaster's impact on Asia's listed firms, with various experts expressing concern over calculating the scale of aid deliveries and recovery efforts.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The tsunami disaster caused significant economic damage across multiple Asian countries, leading to record high stock markets and earnings for listed companies.
However, the economic impact may not be as severe as initially feared.
Some analysts believe that the potential for strong corporate earnings in 2005 may offset some of the loss from the disaster.

The Thai government has estimated the cost of reconstruction at around 30 billion baht ($768 million), while the Maldives is expected to face a staggering economic loss of $12 billion over the next four years due to the destruction caused by the tsunami.

However, it was difficult to assess the magnitude of the disaster and its likely economic impact, as aid and recovery efforts dominated priorities.
The Indian Bombay Stock Exchange inched slightly above its previous record close on Wednesday, while Indonesia's stock exchange in Jakarta hit a record high.
In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index may be benefiting from the potential for its listed property companies to gain from rebuilding contracts in the tsunami-affected regions of South East Asia.
However, Thailand may lose 30bn baht (£398m; $768m) in earnings from tourism over the next three months, according to tourism minister Sontaya Kunplome.
In the affected provinces, he expects the loss of tourism revenue to be offset by government reconstruction spending.
The Maldives could lose hundreds of millions of dollars due to the disaster, and it is still difficult to assess the magnitude of its economic impact.
However, many experts, including the World Bank, have pointed out that it is still difficult to assess the magnitude of the disaster and its likely economic impact.
In part, this is because of its scale, and because delivering aid and recovering the dead remain priorities.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Asian stock markets, including those in Indonesia, India, Hong Kong, Sri Lanka, Thailand, and the Maldives, defied post-tsunami gloom by reaching record highs.
Indonesia's Jakarta stock exchange achieved a new peak due to anticipated strong corporate earnings in 2005.
India's Bombay Stock Exchange also climbed slightly above its previous record close.
Hong Kong's Hang Seng index may benefit from rebuilding contracts in South East Asian regions affected by the tsunami.
Thailand could lose up to 30 billion baht (£398m; $768m) in tourism earnings over three months, but expects reconstruction spending to offset this loss.
Similarly, the Maldives faces potential economic devastation due to reconstruction costs estimated at hundreds of millions of dollars, surpassing its GDP of $660m.
Despite these market gains, experts caution that accurately assessing the disaster's full economic impact is challenging, given the urgent priorities of aid delivery and recovering the dead.
The World Bank, IMF, and other organizations agree that financial calculations will have to wait until reconstruction efforts can be focused on.
